posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Other than the only way its legal is due to a Q&A ruling. Dual powering would normally be explicitly illegal due to R621, as Iâ€™d consider both power options of the radio to be considered a single branch circuit, and R621 states each branch circuit be powered by 1 and only 1 fuse or circuit breaker. From an inspection standpoint, I really donâ€™t like having a Q&A ruling completely overwrite a rule.

Note, that I do think dual powering with 2 breakers should be legal (Except for on the PDP 1.0 due to the port sharing with the PCM ), but it should be properly supported by the rules and not just a Q&A ruling.

posts.cooked: So without the Q&A, how would you advise a team to connect a radio in accordance with R626 (both 12V and POE)

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: Itâ€™s legal according to the Q&A, so itâ€™s allowed. And I guess I didnâ€™t realize that the table for R621 doesnâ€™t include the radio at all, so the radio wiring isnâ€™t at all included in R621, nor is the roboRIO wiring. So the roboRIO and Radio are special cased anyway.

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked: The next poll is going to be â€œWhat gauge wire are you powering your radio with?â€

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked:
We used 2 awg wire to ensure minimal voltage loss for such a critical component.  There are only 3 strands left after trimming down to fit the ports, but Iâ€™m positive it is still worth it.

/s
